text: Members of James Collins’s laboratory (Harvard University) designed a series of matched crRNA/taRNA riboswitches and linked them to various promoters and output genes.
For instance, the device could simultaneously sense a variety of metabolic states in a large batch fermentation system and maximize the efficiency of an industrially attractive pathway.
The and translation of the output gene can now be manipulated by whatever activates the promoters used to express the crRNA and taRNA genes.
The taRNA, once it is made, will promote translation of the output gene by base-pairing with the crRNA.

The Collins group then linked these riboswitches to genes encoding carbon metabolism enzymes and placed them all in the same cell, essentially making a metabolic switchboard that could channel carbon flow through alternative metabolic pathways depending on which riboswitch was activated.
This process can reduce noise in a system.
The design and response of these circuits to various environmental signals is shown in Notice that each riboswitch responded to only one signal.
Metabolic switchboards would have important industrial applications.
riboswitch consists of two parts: a cis-repressed mRNA sequence is linked to an output gene and, by forming a hairpin, hides a ribosome-binding site to prevent translation.
